Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 07:41PM Julia257 wrote: D4Hope, I imagine at that location, you probably appeared to be heavier than you are.  It was great that lipo took care of the situation and made it a non-issue.  Thank you Raeinnz, yes I think I need to wait a few more months and then get back in touch with my surgeon.  She may refer me to a Plastic Surgeon.  It was really wise of you to request the tighter approach and great that he followed your direction.  I'm so glad it worked out so well and that it's out of your way now for those nice long walks and tennis.  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: dog-ears? removal? seltzer Julia257

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2010 05:42PM Julia257 wrote: Good luck Seltzer, I hope it's the best possible result for you with lipo in February, I bet you can't wait.  Please let us know.  I also chose no recon and think it would be great if lipo would do the trick for me.  When in public, so as not to irritate the area, I wear bra w'prosthesis over a thin cotton tshirt then of course something over that.  Even with the past summer heat, the extra layer was not uncomfortable.  I have to admit, it really is a pleasure to rediscover my pre-adolescent stature, bounce free.  I don't miss them at all.  The conversation is very helpful for me too. Have a wonderful weekend!  Julia
Posts.Title: dog-ears? removal? seltzer Julia257

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 02:44PM Julia257 wrote: Thank you for broaching the subject Seltzer, it is my concern as well.  I know it's an insensitive term but dog ear is the best way to describe what's under my left arm after my 2nd Mx in July.  I was wondering Raeinnz, did your original surgeon do the correction after 8 months or was it another doctor?  I don't want to be stuck with it either Bookart, not only is it unsightly (kind of a moot point as who sees it, my boyfriend said who's looking?)  but it is uncomfortable and in the way.  Since it's been 4 months, I'm not sure if I should wait before pursuing a fix or who should do it.  I would greatly appreciate any and all suggestions/input.  Thank you, Julia
Posts.Title: dog-ears? removal? seltzer Julia257

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 08:40PM Julia257 wrote: Thank you for your kindness my friends...wishing you the very best of good health! M, I hope your surgery went well after the delay.  In my situation the Anesthesiologist said that he wasn't concerned as my lungs sounded perfectly clear and my temp. was 97 deg.
Posts.Title: Should I Postpone? Julia257 Julia257

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 01:08PM Julia257 wrote: Oh my God, Swimangel, what an unbelievable nightmare you have gone through. I hope you continue to regain your strength and that you are in the best of health very soon.  And I appreciate so much that you relayed all the details of that horror show to help me and others who may find themselves in a similar situation.  It must have been very painful for you to relive.  You are well named. My PCP's on-call doc said that she doesn't prescribe antibiotics on the phone and that it could be a viral infection anyway, that it's going around.  She said I have a few days, to take acetaminophen and think positively.  At the pharmacy I picked up ColdEze as recommended by the pharmacist so I'm hoping for the best and will definitely keep you posted.  Thanks again for your kindness.
Posts.Title: Should I Postpone? Julia257 Julia257

Posts.Content: Julia257 wrote: I'm scheduled for a mastectomy in 6 days...a 2 1/2 cm mucinous carcinoma this time, 18 years ago it was a .5 cm carcinoma in situ at which time I had a lumpectomy and radiation.  Apparently, this one is fast-growing, I had a so-called negative mammogram 10 months ago.  With worry/fear/lack of sleep and a bug I have bronchitis.  As time is of the essence, I'm reluctant to postpone or even inform my surgeon as she may want to delay.  I could be over this coughing thing by the date of surgery.  Does anyone have any advice?  Would it be very risky to go into surgery with bronchitis or would it be more of a risk to my survival to delay?  Thank you. It's always something! Dx 2/3/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage II, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Should I Postpone? Julia257 Julia257

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 09:00AM Julia257 wrote: I can't thank you wonderful supportive ladies enough for your good wishes and great advice.  I feel the dread and fear that I know you can relate to is lifted by your kindness.  And TCK, I'm encouraged by the fact that your doctors said as long as there's no fever, they could proceed.  The problem is it's a long weekend and to reach my PCP for antibiotics might be difficult.  The service might not consider this an emergency, but I'll try anyway.  I'll let you know.  Thank you all so much.  And I wish you the very best of good health.
